sn16.1:1.2.pli: “Santuṭṭhāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kassapo itarītarena cīvarena, itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī;
sn16.1:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, Kassapa is content with any kind of robe, and praises such contentment.
sn16.1:1.2.comm: This is of course Mahākassapa, “Kassapa the Great”. This chapter paints an indelible personal picture of this great disciple, although I suspect he would have scorned the fame he achieved.

sn16.1:1.3.pli: na ca cīvarahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati; aladdhā ca cīvaraṃ na paritassati; laddhā ca cīvaraṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati.
sn16.1:1.3.eng: He doesn’t employ improper solicitation for the sake of a robe. He doesn’t worry if he doesn’t get a robe. And if he does get a robe, he uses it untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.
sn16.1:1.3.comm: “Improper solicitation” such as hinting, flattery, cosying up to the wealthy, etc.

sn16.1:2.1.pli: Santuṭṭhāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kassapo itarītarena piṇḍapātena, itarītarapiṇḍapātasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī; na ca piṇḍapātahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati; aladdhā ca piṇḍapātaṃ na paritassati; laddhā ca piṇḍapātaṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati.
sn16.1:2.1.eng: Kassapa is content with any kind of almsfood …

sn16.1:3.1.pli: Santuṭṭhāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kassapo itarītarena senāsanena, itarītarasenāsanasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī; na ca senāsanahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati; aladdhā ca senāsanaṃ na paritassati; laddhā ca senāsanaṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati.
sn16.1:3.1.eng: Kassapa is content with any kind of lodging …

sn16.1:4.1.pli: Santuṭṭhāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kassapo itarītarena gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena, itarītaragilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī; na ca gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati; aladdhā ca gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ na paritassati; laddhā ca gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati.
sn16.1:4.1.eng: Kassapa is content with any kind of medicines and supplies for the sick …

sn16.1:5.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ: ‘santuṭṭhā bhavissāma itarītarena cīvarena, itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādino; na ca cīvarahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjissāma;
sn16.1:5.1.eng: So you should train like this: ‘We will be content with any kind of robe, and praise such contentment. We won’t employ improper solicitation for the sake of a robe.

sn16.1:5.2.pli: aladdhā ca cīvaraṃ na ca paritassissāma; laddhā ca cīvaraṃ agadhitā amucchitā anajjhāpannā ādīnavadassāvino nissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjissāma’.
sn16.1:5.2.eng: We won’t worry if we don’t get a robe. And if we do get a robe, we’ll use it untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.’

sn16.1:5.3.eng: (All should be told in full the same way.)

sn16.1:6.1.eng: ‘We will be content with any kind of almsfood …’

sn16.1:6.2.eng: ‘We will be content with any kind of lodging …’

sn16.1:6.3.pli: santuṭṭhā bhavissāma itarītarena gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena, itarītaragilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādino; na ca gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjissāma aladdhā ca gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ na paritassissāma; laddhā ca gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ agadhitā amucchitā anajjhāpannā ādīnavadassāvino nissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjissāmā’ti.
sn16.1:6.3.eng: ‘We will be content with any kind of medicines and supplies for the sick …’

sn16.1:6.5.pli: Kassapena vā hi vo, bhikkhave, ovadissāmi yo vā panassa kassapasadiso, ovaditehi ca pana vo tathattāya paṭipajjitabban”ti.
sn16.1:6.5.eng: I will exhort you with the example of Kassapa or someone like him. You should practice accordingly.”

sn16.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā mahākassapo sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn16.10:1.2.eng: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn16.10:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yenāyasmā mahākassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ etadavoca:
sn16.10:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Mahākassapa and said,

sn16.10:1.4.pli: “āyāma, bhante kassapa, yena aññataro bhikkhunupassayo tenupasaṅkamissāmā”ti.
sn16.10:1.4.eng: “Kassapa, come, sir. Let’s go to one of the nuns’ quarters.”
sn16.10:1.4.comm: Ānanda’s use of “sir” (bhante) here suggests this took place after the Buddha’s passing (DN 16:6.2.3), which is normally the case when the Buddha is not mentioned in the introduction.

sn16.10:1.5.pli: “Gaccha tvaṃ, āvuso ānanda, bahukicco tvaṃ bahukaraṇīyo”ti.
sn16.10:1.5.eng: “You go, Reverend Ānanda. You’re the one with many duties and responsibilities.”
sn16.10:1.5.comm: A certain tension arose between the strict Mahākassapa and the more open Ānanda after the Buddha’s passing. At the First Council, Ānanda was repeatedly admonished by senior monks apparently siding with Kassapa (Kd 21:1.10.2).

sn16.10:1.6.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ etadavoca:

sn16.10:1.7.pli: “āyāma, bhante kassapa, yena aññataro bhikkhunupassayo tenupasaṅkamissāmā”ti.

sn16.10:1.8.pli: “Gaccha tvaṃ, āvuso ānanda, bahukicco tvaṃ bahukaraṇīyo”ti.

sn16.10:1.9.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ etadavoca:
sn16.10:1.9.eng: And a third time, Ānanda said,

sn16.10:1.10.pli: “āyāma, bhante kassapa, yena aññataro bhikkhunupassayo tenupasaṅkamissāmā”ti.
sn16.10:1.10.eng: “Come, Honorable Kassapa. Let’s go to one of the nuns’ quarters.”

sn16.10:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya āyasmatā ānandena pacchāsamaṇena yena aññataro bhikkhunupassayo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn16.10:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Mahākassapa robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went with Venerable Ānanda as his second monk to one of the nuns’ quarters, where he sat on the seat spread out.

sn16.10:2.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhuniyo yenāyasmā mahākassapo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
sn16.10:2.2.eng: And then several nuns went up to Mahākassapa, bowed, and sat down to one side.

sn16.10:2.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho tā bhikkhuniyo āyasmā mahākassapo dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
sn16.10:2.3.eng: Mahākassapa educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired those nuns with a Dhamma talk,

sn16.10:2.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo tā bhikkhuniyo dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
sn16.10:2.4.eng: after which he got up from his seat and left.

sn16.10:3.1.pli: Atha kho thullatissā bhikkhunī anattamanā anattamanavācaṃ nicchāresi:
sn16.10:3.1.eng: But the nun Thullatissā was upset and blurted out,

sn16.10:3.2.pli: “kiṃ pana ayyo mahākassapo, ayyassa ānandassa vedehamunino sammukhā dhammaṃ bhāsitabbaṃ maññati?
sn16.10:3.2.eng: “What is the venerable Mahākassapa thinking, that he’d teach Dhamma in front of the venerable Ānanda, the Videhan sage?
sn16.10:3.2.comm: Ānanda was from Sakya, not Videha, a problem that evidently vexed the commentators. The Pali commentaries explains vedeha as “learned”, or say his mother was from Videha. The Mahāvastu, on the other hand, says that after the Buddha went forth, Ānanda went to Videha and undertook a vow of silence (maunavrata, Mvu 83; Senart 3.176). The Mūlasarvastivāda Vinaya says rather that it was on Mount Videha that the Buddha entrusted Ānanda with the design for the robes (Mu Kd 7; GBM 6.814). None of these are cogent. The point is that Thullatissā was such an idiot, she didn’t even know where Ānanda came from.

sn16.10:3.3.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma sūcivāṇijako sūcikārassa santike sūciṃ vikketabbaṃ maññeyya;
sn16.10:3.3.eng: He’s like a needle peddler who thinks they can sell a needle to a needle maker!”

sn16.10:3.4.pli: evameva ayyo mahākassapo ayyassa ānandassa vedehamunino sammukhā dhammaṃ bhāsitabbaṃ maññatī”ti.

sn16.10:4.1.pli: Assosi kho āyasmā mahākassapo thullatissāya bhikkhuniyā imaṃ vācaṃ bhāsamānāya.
sn16.10:4.1.eng: Mahākassapa heard Thullatissā say these words,

sn16.10:4.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:

sn16.10:4.3.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, āvuso ānanda, ahaṃ sūcivāṇijako, tvaṃ sūcikāro;
sn16.10:4.3.eng: “Is that right, Reverend Ānanda? Am I the needle peddler and you the needle maker?

sn16.10:4.4.eng: Or am I the needle maker and you the needle peddler?”

sn16.10:4.5.eng: “Forgive her, sir. The lady’s a fool.”
sn16.10:4.5.comm: For “lady” (mātugāma), see note on SN 37.3:1.1.

sn16.10:4.6.pli: “Āgamehi tvaṃ, āvuso ānanda, mā te saṅgho uttari upaparikkhi.
sn16.10:4.6.eng: “Hold on, Reverend Ānanda! Don’t make the Saṅgha investigate you further!
sn16.10:4.6.comm: Apparently he is referring to the admonition of Ānanda at the First Council.

sn16.10:5.1.eng: What do you think, Reverend Ānanda?

sn16.10:5.2.pli: api nu tvaṃ bhagavato sammukhā bhikkhusaṅghe upanīto:
sn16.10:5.2.eng: Was it you who the Buddha brought up before the Saṅgha of mendicants, saying:

sn16.10:5.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.10:5.3.eng: ‘Mendicants, whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn16.10:5.4.pli: Ānandopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharatī’”ti?

sn16.10:6.1.pli: “Ahaṃ kho, āvuso, bhagavato sammukhā bhikkhusaṅghe upanīto:
sn16.10:6.1.eng: “I was the one the Buddha brought up before the Saṅgha of mendicants, saying:

sn16.10:6.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.10:6.2.eng: ‘Mendicants, whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn16.10:6.3.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, yāvade ākaṅkhati vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharatī’ti …pe….

sn16.10:6.4.pli: (Navannaṃ anupubbavihārasamāpattīnaṃ pañcannañca abhiññānaṃ evaṃ vitthāro veditabbo.)
sn16.10:6.4.eng: (The nine progressive meditations and the five insights should be told in full.)
sn16.10:6.4.comm: This note referring to the previous Sutta is in the Pali text.

sn16.10:7.1.eng: What do you think, Reverend Ānanda?

sn16.10:7.2.pli: api nu tvaṃ bhagavato sammukhā bhikkhusaṅghe upanīto:
sn16.10:7.2.eng: Was it you who the Buddha brought up before the Saṅgha of mendicants, saying:

sn16.10:7.3.pli: ‘ahaṃ, bhikkhave, āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.10:7.3.eng: ‘I have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And I live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.

sn16.10:7.4.pli: Ānandopi, bhikkhave, āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’”ti?

sn16.10:8.1.pli: “Ahaṃ kho, āvuso, bhagavato sammukhā bhikkhusaṅghe upanīto:
sn16.10:8.1.eng: “I was the one the Buddha brought up before the Saṅgha of mendicants, saying:

sn16.10:8.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ, bhikkhave, āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.10:8.2.eng: ‘I have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And I live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.

sn16.10:8.3.pli: Kassapopi, bhikkhave, āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’ti.

sn16.10:9.1.pli: Sattaratanaṃ vā, āvuso, nāgaṃ aḍḍhaṭṭhamaratanaṃ vā tālapattikāya chādetabbaṃ maññeyya, yo me cha abhiññā chādetabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti.
sn16.10:9.1.eng: Reverend, you might as well think to hide a bull elephant that’s three or three and a half meters tall behind a palm leaf as to hide my six insights.”
sn16.10:9.1.comm: Text has sattaratana, seven “cubits”, i.e. the length from elbow to fingertips, or about 45cm.

sn16.10:10.1.pli: Cavittha ca pana thullatissā bhikkhunī brahmacariyamhāti.
sn16.10:10.1.eng: But the nun Thullatissā fell from the spiritual life.

sn16.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā mahākassapo rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn16.11:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn16.11:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ānando dakkhiṇagirismiṃ cārikaṃ carati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ.
sn16.11:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda was wandering in the Southern Hills together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
sn16.11:1.2.comm: For the Southern Hills or “Deccan” see note on SN 7.11:1.2.

sn16.11:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato ānandassa tiṃsamattā saddhivihārino bhikkhū sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattā bhavanti yebhuyyena kumārabhūtā.
sn16.11:2.1.eng: And at that time thirty of Ānanda’s mendicant protégés resigned the training and returned to a lesser life. Most of them were youths.

sn16.11:2.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando dakkhiṇagirismiṃ yathābhirantaṃ cārikaṃ caritvā yena rājagahaṃ veḷuvanaṃ kalandakanivāpo yenāyasmā mahākassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āyasmā mahākassapo etadavoca:
sn16.11:2.2.eng: When Venerable Ānanda had wandered in the Southern Hills as long as he pleased, he set out for Rājagaha, to the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground. He went up to Venerable Mahākassapa, bowed, and sat down to one side. Mahākassapa said to him:

sn16.11:2.3.pli: “kati nu kho, āvuso ānanda, atthavase paṭicca bhagavatā kulesu tikabhojanaṃ paññattan”ti?
sn16.11:2.3.eng: “Reverend Ānanda, for how many reasons did the Buddha lay down a rule against eating in groups of more than three among families?”
sn16.11:2.3.comm: This is in reference to an event told in Kd 17:3.13.5.1, which refers to the rule on eating in groups at Bu Pc 32. Devadatta cultivated the support of then-Prince Ajātasattu and enjoyed lavish offerings. But with the failure of his attempts to assassinate the Buddha, his reputation disintegrated, so he and his cronies resorted to bugging families for invites for nice meals. The Buddha then banned eating in groups of four or more, except in certain cases. One of the exceptions is while traveling, which would seem to apply in this case. However, Kassapa is not exactly accusing them of breaking the rule, but reminding them of its purpose.

sn16.11:3.1.pli: “Tayo kho, bhante kassapa, atthavase paṭicca bhagavatā kulesu tikabhojanaṃ paññattaṃ—
sn16.11:3.1.eng: “Sir, the Buddha laid down that rule for three reasons.

sn16.11:3.2.pli: dummaṅkūnaṃ puggalānaṃ niggahāya pesalānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ phāsuvihārāya, mā pāpicchā pakkhaṃ nissāya saṅghaṃ bhindeyyuṃ, kulānuddayatāya ca.
sn16.11:3.2.eng: For keeping difficult individuals in check and for the comfort of good-hearted mendicants. To prevent those of corrupt wishes from taking sides and dividing the Saṅgha. And out of consideration for families.
sn16.11:3.2.comm: These reasons are stated at Kd 17:3.13.18 and Pvr 7:33.12. | Devadatta was aiming to create a schism in the Saṅgha, which requires a quorum of at least four mendicants. To succeed, a schism requires not just the Saṅgha, but enough lay support as well. This rule prevents Saṅgha conspiring with lay people.

sn16.11:3.3.pli: Ime kho, bhante kassapa, tayo atthavase paṭicca bhagavatā kulesu tikabhojanaṃ paññattan”ti.
sn16.11:3.3.eng: These are the three reasons why the Buddha laid down that rule.”

sn16.11:4.1.pli: “Atha kiñcarahi tvaṃ, āvuso ānanda, imehi navehi bhikkhūhi indriyesu aguttadvārehi bhojane amattaññūhi jāgariyaṃ ananuyuttehi saddhiṃ cārikaṃ carasi?
sn16.11:4.1.eng: “So what then are you doing, wandering together with these junior mendicants? They don’t guard their sense doors, they eat too much, and they’re not committed to wakefulness.

sn16.11:4.2.pli: Sassaghātaṃ maññe carasi, kulūpaghātaṃ maññe carasi.
sn16.11:4.2.eng: It’s like you’re wandering about wrecking crops and ruining families!

sn16.11:4.3.pli: Olujjati kho te, āvuso ānanda, parisā;
sn16.11:4.3.eng: Your following is falling away, Reverend Ānanda,

sn16.11:4.4.eng: and those just getting started are falling apart.

sn16.11:4.5.eng: Yet this boy knows no limit!”
sn16.11:4.5.comm: Said of a monk sleeping in the Saṅgha (Thag 2.40:2.3) and of Māra (MN 50:21.4).

sn16.11:5.1.pli: “Api me, bhante kassapa, sirasmiṃ palitāni jātāni.
sn16.11:5.1.eng: “Though there are grey hairs on my head,
sn16.11:5.1.comm: Like the previous Sutta, these events probably took place shortly after the Buddha’s passing. The episode with Devadatta occurred only a few years before the Buddha passed away. Ānanda, though traditionally held to be the same age as the Buddha, must have been a generation younger. Here he’s probably around fifty or so, his hair greying, but still young compared with the grizzled ascetic Kassapa.

sn16.11:5.2.pli: Atha ca pana mayaṃ ajjāpi āyasmato mahākassapassa kumārakavādā na muccāmā”ti.
sn16.11:5.2.eng: I still can’t escape being called a boy by Venerable Mahākassapa.”

sn16.11:5.3.pli: “Tathā hi pana tvaṃ, āvuso ānanda, imehi navehi bhikkhūhi indriyesu aguttadvārehi bhojane amattaññūhi jāgariyaṃ ananuyuttehi saddhiṃ cārikaṃ carasi, sassaghātaṃ maññe carasi, kulūpaghātaṃ maññe carasi.
sn16.11:5.3.eng: “It’s because you wander with these junior mendicants. …

sn16.11:5.4.pli: Olujjati kho te, āvuso ānanda, parisā;
sn16.11:5.4.eng: Your following is falling away, Reverend Ānanda,

sn16.11:5.5.eng: and those just getting started are falling apart.

sn16.11:5.6.eng: Yet this boy knows no limit!”

sn16.11:6.1.eng: The nun Thullanandā heard a rumor that

sn16.11:6.2.pli: “ayyena kira mahākassapena ayyo ānando vedehamuni kumārakavādena apasādito”ti.
sn16.11:6.2.eng: the venerable Mahākassapa had rebuked the worthy Ānanda the Videhan sage by calling him a boy.

sn16.11:7.1.pli: Atha kho thullanandā bhikkhunī anattamanā anattamanavācaṃ nicchāresi:
sn16.11:7.1.eng: She was upset and blurted out,

sn16.11:7.2.pli: “kiṃ pana ayyo mahākassapo aññatitthiyapubbo samāno ayyaṃ ānandaṃ vedehamuniṃ kumārakavādena apasādetabbaṃ maññatī”ti.
sn16.11:7.2.eng: “How can the venerable Mahākassapa, who formerly followed another religion, presume to rebuke the venerable Ānanda the Videhan sage by calling him a boy?”
sn16.11:7.2.comm: Not only do Thullanandā and Thullatissā mistakenly think Ānanda was Videhan, they think Kassapa was a convert. Perhaps they are confusing him with fellow brahmins Sāriputta and Moggallāna, who formerly followed the wanderer Sañjaya (Kd 1:23.1.1). As so often, bigotry is the handmaiden of falsehood.

sn16.11:7.3.pli: Assosi kho āyasmā mahākassapo thullanandāya bhikkhuniyā imaṃ vācaṃ bhāsamānāya.
sn16.11:7.3.eng: Mahākassapa heard Thullanandā say these words,

sn16.11:8.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:

sn16.11:8.2.pli: “tagghāvuso ānanda, thullanandāya bhikkhuniyā sahasā appaṭisaṅkhā vācā bhāsitā.
sn16.11:8.2.eng: “Indeed, Reverend Ānanda, the nun Thullanandā spoke rashly and without reflection.

sn16.11:8.3.pli: Yatvāhaṃ, āvuso, kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, nābhijānāmi aññaṃ satthāraṃ uddisitā, aññatra tena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena.
sn16.11:8.3.eng: Since I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness, I don’t recall acknowledging any other teacher apart from the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

sn16.11:8.4.pli: Pubbe me, āvuso, agārikabhūtassa sato etadahosi:
sn16.11:8.4.eng: Formerly when I was still a layman, I thought:

sn16.11:8.5.eng: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.

sn16.11:8.6.pli: Nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
sn16.11:8.6.eng: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

sn16.11:8.7.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
sn16.11:8.7.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
sn16.11:8.7.comm: He renounced independently, not following any school or teacher, much like the Buddha had. Another example is Pukkusāti (MN 140).

sn16.11:8.8.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena paṭapilotikānaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ kāretvā ye loke arahanto te uddissa kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajiṃ.
sn16.11:8.8.eng: After some time I made an outer robe of patches and, in the name of the perfected ones in the world, I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
sn16.11:8.8.comm: MS edition reads the causative kāretvā (“had it made”), but surely Kassapa would have sewn his own robe, so prefer the variant kāritvā found in PTS, BJT, and Thai editions.

sn16.11:9.1.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno addhānamaggappaṭipanno addasaṃ bhagavantaṃ antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandaṃ bahuputte cetiye nisinnaṃ.
sn16.11:9.1.eng: When I had gone forth, I traveled along the road between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā, where I saw the Buddha sitting at the Many Sons Shrine.
sn16.11:9.1.comm: There was another shrine of the same name near Vesālī (DN 16:3.46.3). They were, obviously, fertility shrines.

sn16.11:9.3.eng: ‘Were I ever to see a Teacher, it would be this Blessed One!

sn16.11:9.4.eng: Were I ever to see a Holy One, it would be this Blessed One!

sn16.11:9.5.eng: Were I ever to see a fully awakened Buddha, it would be this Blessed One!’

sn16.11:9.7.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, tattheva bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavocaṃ:
sn16.11:9.7.eng: Then I bowed with my head at the Buddha’s feet and said:

sn16.11:9.8.eng: ‘Sir, the Buddha is my Teacher, I am his disciple!

sn16.11:9.9.eng: The Buddha is my Teacher, I am his disciple!’

sn16.11:9.10.pli: Evaṃ vutte, maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā etadavoca:

sn16.11:9.11.pli: ‘yo kho, kassapa, evaṃ sabbacetasā samannāgataṃ sāvakaṃ ajānaññeva vadeyya jānāmīti, apassaññeva vadeyya passāmīti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyya.
sn16.11:9.11.eng: ‘Kassapa, if anyone was to say to such a wholehearted disciple that they know when they don’t know, or that they see when they don’t see, their head would explode.

sn16.11:9.12.pli: Ahaṃ kho pana, kassapa, jānaññeva vadāmi jānāmīti, passaññeva vadāmi passāmīti.
sn16.11:9.12.eng: But Kassapa, when I say that I know I really do know; and when I say that I see I really do see.

sn16.11:10.1.eng: So you should train like this:

sn16.11:10.2.pli: “tibbaṃ me hirottappaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ bhavissati theresu navesu majjhimesū”ti.
sn16.11:10.2.eng: “I will set up a keen sense of conscience and prudence for seniors, juniors, and those in the middle.”

sn16.11:11.1.eng: And you should train like this:

sn16.11:11.2.pli: “yaṃ kiñci dhammaṃ suṇissāmi kusalūpasaṃhitaṃ sabbaṃ taṃ aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi karitvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇissāmī”ti.
sn16.11:11.2.eng: “Whenever I hear a teaching connected with what’s skillful, I will pay attention, apply the mind, concentrate wholeheartedly, and actively listen to that teaching.”

sn16.11:12.1.eng: And you should train like this:

sn16.11:12.2.eng: “I will never neglect mindfulness of the body that is full of pleasure.”
sn16.11:12.2.comm: For meditation “full of pleasure” (sātasahagata) see AN 8.63 and MN 128:31.4.

sn16.11:13.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iminā ovādena ovaditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
sn16.11:13.1.eng: And when the Buddha had given me this advice he got up from his seat and left.

sn16.11:13.2.pli: Sattāhameva khvāhaṃ, āvuso, saraṇo raṭṭhapiṇḍaṃ bhuñjiṃ aṭṭhamiyā aññā udapādi.
sn16.11:13.2.eng: For seven days I ate the nation’s almsfood as a debtor. On the eighth day I was enlightened.
sn16.11:13.2.comm: Said by Bakkula at MN 124:38.1. See SN 6.1:8.2 and note.

sn16.11:14.1.pli: Atha kho, āvuso, bhagavā maggā okkamma yena aññataraṃ rukkhamūlaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
sn16.11:14.1.eng: And then the Buddha left the road and went to the root of a certain tree.
sn16.11:14.1.comm: The sequence of events is unclear in the text.

sn16.11:14.2.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, āvuso, paṭapilotikānaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ catugguṇaṃ paññapetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavocaṃ:
sn16.11:14.2.eng: So I spread out my outer robe of patches folded in four and said to him,

sn16.11:14.3.pli: ‘idha, bhante, bhagavā nisīdatu, yaṃ mamassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
sn16.11:14.3.eng: ‘Sir, sit here. That would be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’

sn16.11:14.4.pli: Nisīdi kho, āvuso, bhagavā paññatte āsane.
sn16.11:14.4.eng: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out

sn16.11:14.5.pli: Nisajja kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā etadavoca:

sn16.11:14.6.eng: ‘Kassapa, this outer robe of patches is soft.’

sn16.11:14.7.pli: ‘Paṭiggaṇhātu me, bhante, bhagavā paṭapilotikānaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ anukampaṃ upādāyā’ti.
sn16.11:14.7.eng: ‘Sir, please accept my outer robe of patches out of sympathy.’

sn16.11:14.8.pli: ‘Dhāressasi pana me tvaṃ, kassapa, sāṇāni paṃsukūlāni nibbasanānī’ti.
sn16.11:14.8.eng: ‘In that case, Kassapa, will you wear my worn-out hempen rag robe?’

sn16.11:14.10.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, paṭapilotikānaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ bhagavato pādāsiṃ.
sn16.11:14.10.eng: And so I presented my outer robe of patches to the Buddha,

sn16.11:14.11.pli: Ahaṃ pana bhagavato sāṇāni paṃsukūlāni nibbasanāni paṭipajjiṃ.
sn16.11:14.11.eng: and the Buddha presented me with his worn-out hempen rag robe.

sn16.11:15.1.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn16.11:15.1.eng: For if anyone should be rightly called

sn16.11:15.2.pli: ‘bhagavato putto oraso mukhato jāto dhammajo dhammanimmito dhammadāyādo, paṭiggahitāni sāṇāni paṃsukūlāni nibbasanānī’ti, mamaṃ taṃ sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn16.11:15.2.eng: the Buddha’s true-born son, born from his mouth, born of the teaching, created by the teaching, heir to the teaching, and receiver of his worn-out hempen rag robes, it’s me.
sn16.11:15.2.comm: This singular honor took on a mythic significance, for which see Thag 18.1:11.4 and note.

sn16.11:15.3.pli: ‘bhagavato putto oraso mukhato jāto dhammajo dhammanimmito dhammadāyādo, paṭiggahitāni sāṇāni paṃsukūlāni nibbasanānī’ti.

sn16.11:16.1.pli: Ahaṃ kho, āvuso, yāvade ākaṅkhāmi vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn16.11:16.1.eng: Whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. …

sn16.11:16.3.pli: (navannaṃ anupubbavihārasamāpattīnaṃ pañcannañca abhiññānaṃ evaṃ vitthāro veditabbo.)
sn16.11:16.3.eng: (The nine progressive meditations and the five insights should be told in full.)

sn16.11:17.1.pli: Ahaṃ kho, āvuso, āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmi;
sn16.11:17.1.eng: I have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And I live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.

sn16.11:17.2.pli: sattaratanaṃ vā, āvuso, nāgaṃ aḍḍhaṭṭhamaratanaṃ vā tālapattikāya chādetabbaṃ maññeyya, yo me cha abhiññā chādetabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti.
sn16.11:17.2.eng: Reverend, you might as well think to hide a bull elephant that’s three or three and a half meters tall behind a palm leaf as to hide my six insights.”

sn16.11:18.1.pli: Cavittha ca pana thullanandā bhikkhunī brahmacariyamhāti.
sn16.11:18.1.eng: But the nun Thullanandā fell from the spiritual life.

sn16.12:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca mahākassapo āyasmā ca sāriputto bārāṇasiyaṃ viharanti isipatane migadāye.
sn16.12:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa and Venerable Sāriputta were staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.

sn16.12:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā mahākassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā mahākassapena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn16.12:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahākassapa, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn16.12:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ etadavoca:
sn16.12:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Mahākassapa:
sn16.12:1.3.comm: This is a stock series of propositions by non-Buddhists, raised here as a teaching method.

sn16.12:1.4.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, āvuso kassapa, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn16.12:1.4.eng: “Reverend Kassapa, does a realized one still exist after death?”
sn16.12:1.4.comm: An awakened one, whether the Buddha or anyone else, exists after death, for example in an eternal state of Nirvana. | Here “realized one” (tathāgata) pertains to any arahant, as at SN 54.12. The Pali commentary says that a “living being” (satta) is meant. However, tathāgata and satta are exact verbal parallels: tathā (“real”) + gata (“come to the state of”) and sa (“real”) + tta (“state of”). Thus it seems likely that this was originally intended as a mere verbal gloss to resolve the compound. That it does not mean just any sentient being is established at SN 22.86:1.5.

sn16.12:1.5.eng: “Reverend, this has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn16.12:1.7.pli: “Kiṃ panāvuso, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn16.12:1.7.eng: “Well then, does a realized one no longer exist after death?”
sn16.12:1.7.comm: A sage ceases to exist at the time of death. This assumes there is an enduring “self” that is done away with.

sn16.12:1.8.eng: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn16.12:1.10.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn16.12:1.10.eng: “Well then, does a realized one both still exist and no longer exist after death?”
sn16.12:1.10.comm: For example, their body does not exist but their mind does.

sn16.12:1.11.eng: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn16.12:1.12.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.

sn16.12:1.13.pli: “Kiṃ panāvuso, neva hoti, na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti?
sn16.12:1.13.eng: “Well then, does a realized one neither still exist nor no longer exist after death?”
sn16.12:1.13.comm: A sage persists in a subtle state that cannot be characterized in terms of existence or non-existence.

sn16.12:1.14.eng: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn16.12:1.15.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.

sn16.12:1.16.eng: “And why has this not been declared by the Buddha?”

sn16.12:1.17.pli: “Na hetaṃ, āvuso, atthasaṃhitaṃ nādibrahmacariyakaṃ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn16.12:1.17.eng: “Because it’s not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn16.12:1.18.eng: That’s why it has not been declared by the Buddha.”

sn16.12:2.1.eng: “So what now has been declared by the Buddha?”

sn16.12:2.2.eng: “‘This is suffering’ has been declared by the Buddha.

sn16.12:2.5.eng: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’ has been declared by the Buddha.”

sn16.12:2.6.eng: “And why has this been declared by the Buddha?”

sn16.12:2.7.pli: “Etañhi, āvuso, atthasaṃhitaṃ etaṃ ādibrahmacariyakaṃ etaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn16.12:2.7.eng: “Because it’s beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn16.12:2.8.eng: That’s why it has been declared by the Buddha.”
